name: Avadon: The Black Fortress
description: Avadon: The Black Fortress is an epic, Indie fantasy role-playing saga.

reviews.review_text: If you're familiar with Spiderweb Software's RPGs, it will come as no surprise that Avadon: The Black Fortress is another extensive old school party-based trek through areas full of nooks and crannies with unique encounters and secret loot caches to be had, as well as exciting set piece encounters and an intriguing overall narrative. That's pretty much true of everything they put out. The big changes to the formula are: a new world; a significantly more linear progression than most of the other entries in their lineup, a class-and-skill-tree approach to character builds, and party members who are fully fledged NPCs that contribute insights and dialogue throughout the plot as you move through it, can be spoken to between missions, and have their own side agendas you will have to deal with.  The new world is an intriguing fantasy setting where five disparate and feuding lands have banded together in a defensive pact against pirates, invading empires, marauding humanoids and dragons, a blighted magical corruption, and other exterior threats. The pact is held together by the dictatorial enforcement of the Black Fortress Avadon, and they maintain a network of spies and enforcement agents to ensure compliance. The fairly unique conceit of this particular entry (and who knows, perhaps followup games in the series) is that you play Hands of Avadon, sent to enforce the laws of the pact and defend it from threats within and without. This gives you rather more authority and a much more fearsome reputation than your typical band of wandering adventurers, and this is used to good effect throughout, although alas you still have to contend with buying your own supplies, a tired RPG trope that seems even more out of place in this context (though they do attempt to explain it).  The linearity is somewhat unfortunate, but things do open up as you gain access to more of the areas and return to zones on new missions, and most of the sidequests can be done at your leisure. Still, the flipside of linearity is that you're always being sent into challenges that you should be equipped to handle, and it's always clear what you're expected to do next, neither of which are guaranteed in more open formats.  I am personally a big fan of Avadon's approach to skills and classes. I find the structure of new ability at rank 1, additional effect(s) at later ranks, and unlocking a secondary ability at a late rank very rewarding and I never feel like my points are wasted or that I have to save points from level to level just to advance at all, which have been issues I've historically had with the more freeform skill approach earlier Spiderweb games took (and other games with skill systems, for that matter). And Avernum in particular suffered from boring fighter syndrome where spellcasters got huge suites of spells to cast for a varied combat experience and fighters...got to hit things. Not here. The Blademaster class even passively is a blast, with heavy passive investment rewarding cleaves, a hilariously effective level of hit prevention, and the chance to riposte, curse enemies, or begin regenerating if hit, and then on top of that gets group buffs and debuffs and attacks with additional secondary effects. The Shadowwalker hurls shurikens, teleports around, throws pots of acid and smoke bombs, backstabs and poisons, and is a huge fountain of damage in general. (Needless to say, I was pleased when the Avernum remake cribbed from this system, albeit in a more Avernum-y way.)  As for the NPCs - there's one of every type, you get them all pretty nearly immediately, they stay levelled with you even if you're not using them, and they all have interesting personalities and backstories. I've never been a huge fan of the 'party too large for everyone to simultaneously adventure with you' thing, but this is about as good as it gets considering that.  So all in all, another classic RPG. It's not quite as old school as previous series from Spiderweb, but the deviations from that formula mostly are in the vein of improvements in RPG design, in my book, not stepping away from the core appeal.

Let me just say, I love all of the Spiderweb games. That being said, Avadon just might be their best game. While it is most definitely more linear than Geneforge or Avernum, the story and companion dialogue more than make up for it. You can spend the game looking for twists on your first playthrough, but I would bet that you wouldn't be able to guess most of what happens, especially because a decent amount of plot direction depends on what decisions you make. Whenever you hear someone say something like, 'For a game to be immersive it has to have fantastic graphics and a mega budget', show them this. I feel very fulfilled having just finished this game for the first time, and feel a compelling urge to start a second playthrough. Do yourself a favor and buy this game.

Classic Spiderweb RPG - although a little worse than Avernum: Escape from the Pit which I played previously.  + Long and rich story with decisions + many quests and companion quests + character development  - linear story with same locations - very easy difficulty compared to Avernum  If you are a fan of these games you should play it.  If you are not familiar with Spiderweb games - try Avernum: Escape from the Pit instead!

Think Baldur's Gate. Think old-school. But indie, and made by one man.  It's a turn based tactical rpg with a rich story dependant on playerchoices. The start might be a little slow, you might fight off hordes of trashmobs that might seem a bit redundant. But it's a really good political/fantasy story where you can roleplay your character.  So play it...yup.

Not Spiderweb Soft's best work. Not even close. Boss fights can be HORRIBLY unbalanced. Been trying to beat the final guy for over an hour, on the lowest difficulty setting with a max level party and the best weapons/equipment in the game according to what info I can find online. Attacks that did ~80 damage to the previous boss now do at most 14 damage to him. His health bar hasn't moved a single pixel in the last twenty minutes. And the kicker? I've been using the cheat codes every single turn. Pretty much have to, the boss gets 5 actions most turns which he uses to apply conditions to all 3 party members. He keeps magically yanking his own soul out to create golems that make him completely immune to specific types of damage. Have to spend 2-5 turns smashing the golem before being able to touch him and most hits are registering damage in the single digits. Pure frustration.

It' runs like a cross between Baldur's gate and Fallout (the REAL Fallout, not the Bethesda one)with crap graphics. HOWEVER, if you are one of those people who dont really give a damn about graphics, you will find an amazingly well written RPG that makes you long for the late 90s.   Personally I get sick of people whining about graphics all the time. ITS AN INDIE RPG, PEOPLE. You want graphics, go buy a big budget 'RPG'.    RPGs like this sure beat out that crap fest EA threw out called Dragon Age 2, tiny bad graphics and all.
Classic, old-school gaming at its best! Once you let yourself get involved with the story, there is not turning back until you reach its end.

Spiderweb Software have pretty much been trying to build on the same formula for a long time, so if you like any other SpiderSoft games, you'll like this. Decent story, decent writing, decent combat/tactics. It's a capable game, and you could do a lot worse. Of course, you could do better too.

Game was simple but fun until the end. Trying to engage in the fight with Redbeard at the end was as frustrating as the message boards promised. That element really soured it for me, so I will probably not buy another Avadon game.
Great classic-style RPG.
Classic Spiderweb style, sans the incredibly rubbish artwork the company has always been plagued with. Buy it here, you'll not find it cheaper anywhere else.
If you played any of the games made by this company back in the day, you'll like this game. Spiderweb was a staple of gaming back when I was forced to play on a Mac as a kid.
This has an old-school feel to it, which is excellent.
it's like an extremely simplified baldurs gate but still fun

This is a fantastic turn-based party-oriented single player, story focused, old-school western-style RPG similar to the types of games that came out in the era just before Baldur's Gate (or very similar to BG if you play BG is auto-pause mode). The graphics are a little rough around the edges, but they have a unique charm. The story and choices that you make which have a lasting impact on the story branches available to you is really good. Characterization is not quite as good as, say, Planescape, or DAO, but still pretty good, you do get a feel for your companions and their unique personalities. I am probably only about 10 or 12 hours into this game but I've played it on a few different platforms at the same time, and I can verify that what class you choose and the companions you choose to take along with you can dramatically change the game play and even the story to some extent (choices available to you). I like the skill tree, it makes it so that even if you decide to be a shaman and also take the NPC shaman with you, you won't be carbon copies, you can be two distinctly different types of characters with their own role in the party dynamics. While I have not beat this, I've gotten far enough to easily recommend this to anyone. Besides, there is a free demo if you want to spend an hour or so to see if it is your bag.
Marvelous, old-school for-the-win :)

This is truly a classic style, third person, turn based, roll playing game. It is reminisant if the SSI gold box series, similar to Buldar's Gate but not as emursive or has as much freedom in the games story. This game is not perfect but over all it has a very good story with some decision based lines and out comes. In order to complete some quests and parts of the story I did have to use a general game over view guide and codes easly found on the internet. I don't think it is posable to complete the game with out a basic guide or using some codes (even on normal) as the quest system is very simplistic and some of the fights are far too hard(not unlike some of the calssic games). Qusets do not up date on every step so it is sometimes hard to know exactly where to go and what to do. There was an excessive amount of dialog to read in the game. It was great that i could control up to three cahricters at a time even though only one was rolled by me. Over all a good game. If you like turn based RPG's and classic RPG's you should check this game out!

This is absolutely one of the biggest disappointments I've ever had on Steam. Please - check my reviews, I'm no troll. In fact, this may be my first bad review. However - this game is a mess. It hangs up, saved games aren't reliable, the screen settings aren't reliable... read the forums. The most posted involve the game bugging and not continuing (in any of a number of ways/quests). What's sad ISN'T that a game has bugs (though for a coding as old as this, it almost is) but that NOTHING is done to alleviate them in the years its been out? This game is continuing to be sold - they rewrote it for Ipad - and it has the same quest lockups/resolution issues! I'm sorry to say it (because I've TRIED to like this game) but it's not worth it. Look elsewhere.

Don't get me wrong, Avadon is a pretty decent RPG, and has all the strengths I've come to expect from Spiderweb (strong story, good humor, etc). The thing is though...I just couldn't get into it. I can't even really explain why, it just wasn't for me.  Its by no means a bad game. Its just a game that I can't see myself playing much.

This is a strikingly old school title with primitive graphics, but the combat was fun and the story was good. I had fun with it. Probably not for anybody under age 40, though, as the graphics are straight out of the 1980s. Only someone who played games of this type when they were state of the art (or someone intensely curious as to what the old games were like) will be able to suspend disbelief with the limited help this level of graphics can provide. On the other hand, in the way that books can hold a type of magic that movies cannot, graphics aren't always the end all and be all of a good game design.
Fun party-based single-player strategy RPG.   A little too focused on forced-choice situations, but most RPGs have that problem these days.

I played some of spiderweb software's earlier games when I was a kid, so I have some heavy nostalgia as I go into any of their products. ...unfortunately, Avadon doesn't quite follow through. Although it really really could, if it had been polished more.  The combat system is technically balanced and reasonable, but comes across as slow and plodding. You have to sit through the entirety of every attack animation followed by a brief pause, for every action any character takes, before it will load the interface for the next character's turn -- which isn't so bad, the first hundred times you see the basic attack animation. Combat also activates too soon, a lot of the time-- it can take several turns of walking before anyone is in range; and that walking may take you far out of your intended travel path...and into line of sight of more enemies, that can repeat the process. It can also be difficult to tell at a glance whose turn it is, until you figure out what to look for, and sometimes the hitboxes of tightly grouped combatants overlap a bit (making it hard to select the right one). Previous games also had a significantly more varied spell list -- the list has been easily halved, although the list of abilities for mundane combat characters has grown noticeably. In short, there is nothing cripplingly wrong with the combat in this game, and it CAN be interesting and fun (particularly against named unique enemies) -- but it could have been so much better, so easily.  The game's story centers around being a new member of the secret police for a dubiously moral authoritarian medieval city-state, which keeps the peace for an alliance of five nations. Which is excellent and unique. All the characters are interesting, dialogue is interesting, and I will play this thing through to the end to see how it goes (..and then again with a ninja or sorceress; so I will have enough lockpicks to get through all the locked doors this time). Unfortunately, that good dialogue and the interestingly-designed quests that go with it happen to be implemented as poorly as the combat system. In one case, the only way to destroy a piece of evidence is to go talk to the local captain of the guards about it (and not the spymaster for your kingdom; only the local guardsman will do), and after bringing it up, choose 'Never mind. [destroy evidence]'. How are you supposed to find that option, unless you've already decided to turn the evidence in instead?  The quests in this game are far, far too easy to break; and I find myself enjoying the story not because of their craftsmanship in game design...but in spite of it. Even with that caveat, I can't deny that I AM largely enjoying it, and particularly the fact that even though they force too many situations to boil down to simple binary choices, it's often not 'right' vs. 'wrong'. It might be tradition vs. cultural innovation, freedom vs. security (vs. duty), or even just choosing whether or not to accept someone's offer to surrender/ flee. ..I'm finding that a lot of my choices get overruled though, with circumstance forcing everyone into how the narrative WOULD have gone if I'd chosen the other way. I'm not sure if this is a magician's choice scenario, or just bad luck on my part. In any case...  If you want to play the secret police of a medieval magical mind-break-the-prisoners authoritarian citystate, with free reign to just do whatever you want to anyone you want, a reasonably complex and realistic political climate, and turn-based combat that is fine but slowish, give Avadon a try. ...but expect to experience the story as they laid it out (with occasional breaks for mass-effect style Paragon/Renegage options), rather than actually control your path.

Avadon is a great game initially which quickly becomes a complete chore. Quests stack up and become really tough to manage, it's difficult to find NPC's once you've completed a quest (in a really huge map), quest journals don't update properly when you've completed a quest, etc. It's a massive, massive game with a lot of potential. Hopefully Avadon 2 is better...
Fun classic isometric RPGs. Certainly not innovative but competently done. If you like it be sure to check out Spiderweb Software's other offerings.

A fantastic CRPG that excels in every aspect. Turn-based, tactical combat that finds a comfortable balance of speed and challenge. An immense world that rewards exploration and (surprisingly) remains interesting throughout--it never feels repetitive or empty as every corner hides a new discovery and reward. The characters are beliveable and the choices they offer meaningful--in large part due to the amazing writing which is what really shines the most and ties everything together to create such an awesome, engrossing experience.
For anyone missing storylines, I own all of spiderweb softwares games. The moral questions raised in each are gripping ... in the same manner as a novel, or flash game, as opposed to video game.

For me, the failure of Avadon is in the setting. It's crapsacktacular, with every significant NPC being a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and all the various factions being murderous, amoral thugs. I simply got tired of continuing the game in the face of hating everybody in it.

Avadon is a great game initially which quickly becomes a complete chore. Quests stack up and become really tough to manage, it's difficult to find NPC's once you've completed a quest (in a really huge map), quest journals don't update properly when you've completed a quest, etc. It's a massive, massive game with a lot of potential. Hopefully Avadon 2 is better...
If you grew up on 90s pc RPGs, you MUST GET THIS GAME. Cool skill trees, epic story, awesome turn based, grid based, tactical combat. 4 Classes. It's very good.

Do you like oldschool RPGs? Then you should probably grab Avadon, because at $10 it's a steal.   It may not be Vogel's best game ( Geneforge/Avernum are apparently better ), but it's good enough to remind me why I got in to gaming in the first place, and modern enough to keep me from getting frusterated by old mechanics.
Old skool RPG fun but gets a bit tedious and same-same after a while. Worth investing some time in it if you like these sort of games as there's plenty of gameplay here for your $10.
This game is fun. I can't wait to explore more of the world!
A pretty cool blend of classic and modern WRPG. Original setting and lore, decent story, adequate graphics and unremarkable audio.
